content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" as per the Small Business Act. It also establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. SEC. 3. OFFICE OF ENTREPRENEURIAL EDUCATION. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section on Entrepreneurial Education. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section on Entrepreneurial Education, establishing the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Administration. This office will provide innovative entrepreneurial information, education, and resources to support prospective entrepreneurs and successful small businesses. The Director of the Office reports to the Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development and is responsible for developing and delivering these services. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education manages online courses, publications, and resources for entrepreneurs and small business concerns, as well as youth entrepreneurship programs. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education oversees online courses, publications, and resources for entrepreneurs and small businesses, as well as youth entrepreneurship programs including online resources and coordination with service providers. The Administration coordinates with service providers to support youth entrepreneurs in starting or expanding small businesses. They also collaborate with private sector partners to share educational materials on money management and financial literacy for entrepreneurs and small business owners. The Administration supports youth entrepreneurs in starting or expanding small businesses by coordinating with service providers and private sector partners to share educational materials on money management and financial literacy. They also provide assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in issues related to entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will establish a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program within a year of the Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act enactment. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will establish a program to provide grants for technical assistance to primary and secondary schools within a year of the Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act enactment. The Associate Administrator may grant funds to nonprofit organizations, such as small business development centers, SCORE chapters, and women's business centers, to offer technical assistance to schools for entrepreneurship programs. Nonprofits must submit an application outlining project goals to receive a grant. Nonprofit organizations can receive grants for entrepreneurship programs by submitting applications with project goals and partner lists to the Associate Administrator. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants for entrepreneurship programs must provide project goals, partner lists, and any other necessary information determined by the Associate Administrator. Within one year of receiving the grant, a report detailing the individuals assisted must be submitted to the Associate Administrator. Nonprofit organizations must submit a report within one year of receiving a grant, detailing the individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must report on the individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information within one year. Authorization of appropriations is set at $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2013-2015. Authorization of appropriations is set at $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2013-2015 to carry out entrepreneurial education programs. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report to the Senate and House committees on best practices in entrepreneurial education programs in the US within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include descriptions of exemplary programs determined by the Director. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education will submit a report to Congress on exemplary entrepreneurial education programs in the US, including national, regional, state, and local programs, as well as programs by the Federal Government, state and local governments, and nonprofit organizations. The report will include information on entrepreneurial education programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as programs by the Federal Government, state and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. SEC. 4. MASTER OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION SCHOLARSHIP PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. The Administrator may award scholarships to MBA students for providing free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of the recipients must be students at institutions of higher education. The scholarships awarded to MBA students require at least 50% of recipients to be from institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. Activities supported include various small business and entrepreneurial projects. The activities supported by scholarships include independent investigator-led, interdisciplinary, and multi-institutional projects. Each student receiving a scholarship has a mentor to help them relate their academic studies to the projects. Each student receiving a scholarship under subsection (a) has a mentor to help relate their academic studies to the assistance provided under the agreement. Data collection requires students and small businesses to provide information on the use and results of the assistance. Data collection requires students and small businesses to provide information on the use and results of the assistance received, as well as employment status for 3 years after the student's expected graduation date. Failure to comply with the agreement may result in scholarship repayment. The agreement requires students to provide information on the use of assistance and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply may result in scholarship repayment. The agreement mandates that students who fail to provide required information post-graduation will have their scholarship converted into a Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loan, subject to repayment with interest. The Administrator is authorized $200,000 annually from 2013 to 2015 for this purpose. The Administrator is authorized $200,000 annually from 2013 to 2015 for scholarships under this section, with a sunset date of September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues and sponsor competitions among small businesses and inventors. The regional administrator of each office will identify public-private issues and sponsor regional competitions for small businesses and inventors to address these challenges. Outreach will be provided to universities, colleges, business communities, and industry leaders. The regional administrator sponsors regional competitions for small businesses and inventors to address challenges. Outreach is provided to universities, colleges, business communities, industry leaders, and organizations to promote the competition and request proposals for research and business plans. The regional administrator sponsors competitions for small businesses and inventors. Outreach is provided to universities, colleges, and organizations to promote the competition and request proposals for research and business plans. Selected plans are submitted to the Administrator in a report. The Administrator organizes a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans addressing entrepreneurship education issues. The Administrator organizes a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans on entrepreneurship education issues. A panel of 11 employees will select the plans presented at the conference. The Administrator will designate 11 employees to serve on a panel that selects the best research and business plans addressing entrepreneurship education issues at the national conference. The Administrator will designate employees to serve on a panel selecting the best plans addressing entrepreneurship education issues at the national conference. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to individuals or groups with selected plans, with employees from the principal and regional offices involved in the selection process. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected individuals or groups, who must submit a report on the grant's use within a year. $750,000 is authorized for the Administrator to carry out this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship by providing capital for business formation.
